subSections.title: Definitions
Compounds
subSections.text: {{zh-der|彈鋏|彈鋏無魚|鋏腳|長鋏|馮諼彈鋏|鱗鋏星鐔|鋏子|長鋏}}

subSections.title: Readings
Etymology 1
subSections.text:
{{wikipedia|lang=ja|はさみ}} [[File:Small_Scissors.jpg|thumb|250px|{{lang|ja|鋏}} (''hasami''): a pair of traditional Japanese '''shears''' or '''scissors'''.]] [[File:Scissor.JPG|thumb|250px|{{lang|ja|鋏}} (''hasami''): a pair of western-style '''scissors'''.]] {{wikipedia|Scissors}}
{{ja-kanjitab|はさみ|yomi=k}} Originally the {{m|ja|連用形|tr=ren'yōkei||stem or continuative form}} of verb {{m|ja|鋏む|tr=hasamu||to be tightly between two things, to be inserted in between”}},{{R:Kokugo Dai Jiten}}{{R:Daijirin}} itself apparently deriving from ''hasa'' (“narrowness between other things”, likely cognate with {{ja-l|細}} ''hoso'', “skinny, narrowness within the thing itself”) + auxiliary suffix {{m|ja|む|tr=mu||to be or become like something}}. Cognate and homophonic with {{ja-l|挟}}, {{ja-l|挿||hasami}}: “being stuck in between other things”.

subSections.title: Noun
subSections.text:
{{ja-noun|はさみ}}

# [[scissors]], a [[pair]] of scissors
# [[pincers]] or [[claw]]s as found on a [[crab]], [[lobster]], or other [[arthropod]]
# a [[punch]] as used to make a hole in a piece of paper

subSections.title: Usage notes
subSections.text:
The ''scissors'' and ''punch'' senses are also found spelled {{ja-l|剪刀}}.

The ''arthropod pincers'' sense is also found spelled {{ja-l|螯}} and {{ja-l|鉗}}.

subSections.title: Idioms
subSections.text: * {{ja-r|鋏を入れる|はさみ を いれる}}: “to put the scissors in” → to cut with scissors; to punch a ticket; to trim vegetation or hair

subSections.title: Derived terms
subSections.text:
{{der-top}}
* {{ja-r|鋏状価格差|はさみ-じょう かかくさ}}: [[w:Price scissors|price scissors]]
* {{ja-r|鋏虫|はさみむし}}: an [[earwig]]
* {{ja-r|鋏虫目|はさみむし もく}}: [[order]] ''[[Dermaptera]]'', the [[earwig]]s
* {{ja-r|鋏盤|はさみばん}}: a mechanical [[shear]] for cutting metal
{{der-mid}}
* {{ja-r|金鋏|かなばさみ}}: [[blacksmith]]'s [[gripper]]s
* {{ja-r|紙鋏|かみばさみ}}: paper [[scissors]]
* {{ja-r|空鋏|からばさみ}}: working a pair of [[scissors]] to make the sound of cutting, without actually cutting anything
* {{ja-r|木鋏|きばさみ}}: long [[shears]] for pruning, such as for a [[hedge]]
* {{ja-r|銀葉鋏|ぎんよう-ばさみ}}: [[tweezers]] for holding [[silver leaf]] in traditional Japanese [[incense]]
* {{ja-r|西洋鋏|せいよう-ばさみ}}: [[western]]-style [[scissors]]
* {{ja-r|裁ち鋏|たちばさみ}}: [[scissors]] for cutting [[cloth]]
* {{ja-r|爪切り鋏|つめきり-ばさみ}}: [[nail clippers]]
* {{ja-r|唐鋏|とうばさみ}}: [[western]]-style [[scissors]], with a pivot in the center and forming an X shape
* {{ja-r|握り鋏|にぎりばさみ}}: traditional Japanese [[shears]], with a join at the back end and forming a U shape
* {{ja-r|花鋏|はなばさみ}}: [[flower]] [[shears]], [[florist]]'s [[scissors]]
* {{ja-r|ピンキング鋏|ピンキング-ばさみ}}: [[pinking]] [[shears]]
* {{ja-r|洋鋏|ようばさみ}}: [[western]]-style [[scissors]]
* {{ja-r|和鋏|わばさみ}}: traditional Japanese [[shears]], with a join at the back end and forming a U shape
* {{ja-r|矢床鋏|やっとこばさみ}}: [[blacksmith]]'s [[gripper]]s
{{der-bottom}}

subSections.title: Etymology 2
subSections.text:
{{wikipedia|やっとこ}} [[File:Smith-gripper_hg.jpg|thumb|250px|{{lang|ja|鋏}} (''yattoko''): a pair of blacksmith's '''pincers''']]
{{ja-kanjitab|やっとこ|yomi=k}} Probably originally an abbreviation of synonym ''yattokobasami'', with the ''yattoko'' portion possibly an alteration of {{m|ja|焼き床|tr=yakidoko||the cooking bed of an oven, or the firing bed of a kiln|pos=possibly formerly read as ''yakitoko''|lit=burning or cooking bed}}, perhaps used as a dialect word referring to the [[forge]]; compare {{m|ja|火床|tr=hidoko|lit=fire bed||hearth; a firepit, such as beneath a boiler}}.

subSections.title: Noun
subSections.text:
{{ja-noun|やっとこ}}

# [[pincers]], [[nippers]], [[pliers]], [[tongs]], or [[grippers]], specifically those used to hold a metal object being worked in [[blacksmithing]]

subSections.title: Derived terms
Etymology 3
subSections.text:
{{ja-kanjitab|やとこ|yomi=k}}
Probable variation from ''yattoko''. Rare.<ref name="KDJ"/>

subSections.title: Noun
subSections.text:
{{ja-noun|やとこ}}

# {{lb|ja|sort=やとこ|rare}} [[pincers]], [[nippers]], [[pliers]], [[tongs]], or [[grippers]], more specifically those used to hold a metal object being worked in [[blacksmithing]]

subSections.title: Etymology 4
Derived terms
